yeah
if you've got 686 and it's running fine, you shouldn't need to have 386 on your system I don't believe.
it shouldn't give updates for packages you don't have.
i agree. the updater is still there telling me i need this. how do i get rid of it?
forcing the version (you can do this in Synaptic) would be what I would try.
ok i'll give it a shot.
you know how to do that?
no, i was about to go look in synaptic to see how
select the package and go to Package>Lock Version.
you mean lock 686, right? btw the 'write to cd' option worked. =]
no - lock 386.  The lock version makes it so you don't get updates for the package.   -- Cool, glad it worked :)
the kernel you boot with should still be 686.
